critters.name: White-tailed Deer
critters.summary: Common woodland browser often seen near fields and feeders.
critters.fact: White-tailed deer use their white tail as a flag to signal danger to other deer.
critters.activeFact: White-tailed deer can jump about 8 feet high and clear long obstacles when alarmed.

critters.name: Black Bear
critters.summary: Largest forest mammal in Michigan woodlands.
critters.fact: Black bears have an excellent sense of smell, up to seven times better than a bloodhound's.
critters.activeFact: Black bears are strong climbers and can shimmy up trees fast, even as adults.

critters.name: Coyote
critters.summary: Adaptable predator common in rural areas.
critters.fact: Coyotes are highly adaptable, thriving in deserts, forests, mountains, and even urban areas.
critters.activeFact: Coyotes use body language like tail position and ear angle as much as they use vocal calls.

critters.name: Red Fox
critters.summary: Solitary hunter active in open woods and fields.
critters.fact: Red foxes use their bushy tails for balance and as warm covers in cold weather.
critters.activeFact: Red foxes can hear small prey moving under snow, then pounce to break through the crust.

critters.name: Gray Fox
critters.summary: Smaller fox species able to climb trees.
critters.fact: Gray foxes are excellent climbers, often seen climbing trees to escape predators or find food.
critters.activeFact: Gray foxes can rotate their wrists to climb like a cat, helping them escape danger in trees.

critters.name: Bobcat
critters.fact: Bobcats have unique, spotted fur that helps them blend seamlessly into forests and rocky terrain.
critters.activeFact: Bobcats often cover leftover food with leaves or snow and return later, like a wild pantry stash.

critters.name: Porcupine
critters.fact: Porcupines have sharp quills that detach easily to deter predators, acting as effective natural armor.
critters.activeFact: Porcupines have orange front teeth from iron-rich enamel that keeps them tough and sharp.

critters.name: Beaver
critters.fact: Beavers build dams that create ponds, providing habitats for many other wildlife species.
critters.activeFact: Beavers slap the water with their tail as an alarm signal to warn others of danger.

critters.name: Muskrat
critters.summary: Small aquatic rodent near ponds and streams.
critters.fact: Muskrats build lodges using plants and mud, similar to beaver dams but smaller and less complex.
critters.activeFact: Muskrats often have underwater entrances to their lodges, keeping them safer from predators.

critters.name: Mink
critters.fact: Minks are excellent swimmers, using their partially webbed feet to hunt fish and amphibians underwater.
critters.activeFact: Minks can hunt both in water and on land, switching tactics depending on whatâ€™s available.

critters.name: Fisher
critters.fact: Fishers are skilled climbers that use trees to escape predators and hunt prey efficiently.
critters.activeFact: Fishers are agile enough to hunt in trees and on the ground, making them tricky predators to spot.

critters.name: River Otter
critters.summary: Playful aquatic predator found near rivers.
critters.fact: River otters can close their ears and nostrils underwater to stay fully submerged while hunting.
critters.activeFact: River otters use whiskers to detect vibrations in the water, helping them find fish in murky spots.

critters.name: Eastern Gray Squirrel
critters.fact: Eastern Gray Squirrels can find nuts buried beneath a foot of snow using their strong sense of smell.
critters.activeFact: Eastern gray squirrels use a zigzag sprint pattern to make it harder for predators to catch them.

critters.name: American Red Squirrel
critters.fact: American Red Squirrels fiercely defend their food caches, storing thousands of seeds for winter survival.
critters.activeFact: Red squirrels stockpile cones in big piles called â€œmiddens,â€ like a tiny forest warehouse.

critters.name: Chipmunk
critters.summary: Ground squirrel known for cheek pouches.
critters.fact: Chipmunks can store food in cheek pouches to carry back to their burrows efficiently.
critters.activeFact: Chipmunks can carry surprising amounts of food by packing their cheek pouches like grocery bags.

critters.name: Snowshoe Hare
critters.summary: Forest rabbit with seasonal coat change.
critters.fact: Snowshoe hares change fur color seasonally for camouflage: brown in summer, white in snowy winter.
critters.activeFact: Snowshoe hare feet act like natural snowshoes, spreading weight so they donâ€™t sink as easily.

critters.name: Eastern Cottontail
critters.fact: Eastern Cottontails can run up to 18 miles per hour to escape predators.
critters.activeFact: Eastern cottontails rely on stillness and camouflage first, then explode into a fast zigzag run.

critters.name: Raccoon
critters.fact: Raccoons wash their food in water before eating, a behavior called "dousing" seen mostly in captivity.
critters.activeFact: Raccoons have extremely nimble â€œhandsâ€ and can turn latches and knobs with practice.

critters.name: Opossum
critters.fact: Opossums are the only North American marsupials and can hang by their tails!
critters.activeFact: Opossums have a low body temperature, which makes rabies infections less likely compared to many mammals.

critters.name: Striped Skunk
critters.summary: Night forager known for defensive spray.
critters.fact: Striped skunks can spray a foul-smelling liquid up to 10 feet to defend themselves from predators.
critters.activeFact: Skunks give warning signs first, like stamping feet and lifting the tail, before they spray.

critters.name: Flying Squirrel
critters.fact: Flying squirrels can glide up to 150 feet using a special membrane between their limbs.
critters.activeFact: Flying squirrels steer mid-glide by shifting their body and using their tail like a rudder.

critters.name: Little Brown Bat
critters.fact: Little Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects mid-flight, making them expert nighttime hunters.
critters.activeFact: Little brown bats can catch insects on the wing using echolocation that works like sonar.

critters.name: Big Brown Bat
critters.fact: Big Brown Bats use echolocation to hunt insects, catching up to half their body weight in one night.
critters.activeFact: Big brown bats often roost in buildings and can help control night insects around lights.

critters.name: Barred Owl
critters.summary: Woodland owl known for 'who cooks for you' call.
critters.fact: Barred Owls have distinctive hoots that sound like "Who cooks for you? Who cooks for you all?"
critters.activeFact: Barred owls can glide silently because their feathers have soft edges that reduce flight noise.

critters.name: Great Horned Owl
critters.fact: Great Horned Owls have powerful talons that can kill prey as large as skunks or raccoons.
critters.activeFact: Great horned owls can grip prey with powerful talons and often reuse nests built by other birds.

critters.name: Blue Jay
critters.summary: Bold feeder visitor with loud calls.
critters.fact: Blue Jays can mimic the calls of hawks to scare away other birds from their territory.
critters.activeFact: Blue jays cache food in multiple spots, then relocate it later using strong memory.

critters.name: Northern Cardinal
critters.fact: Northern Cardinals are known for their bright red feathers and distinctive, clear whistling songs.
critters.activeFact: Cardinals are early singers, often calling at dawn even before the light fully hits the woods.

critters.name: Black-capped Chickadee
critters.fact: Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food throughout winter.
critters.activeFact: Chickadees can lower their body temperature at night to conserve energy during cold spells.

critters.name: Tufted Titmouse
critters.fact: Tufted Titmice often chatter loudly to communicate and defend their territory from intruders.
critters.activeFact: Tufted titmice often grab one seed, fly off, crack it open, then repeat like clockwork.

critters.name: White-breasted Nuthatch
critters.summary: Tree climber often moving headfirst down bark.
critters.fact: White-breasted Nuthatches can climb down trees headfirst, a unique behavior among birds.
critters.activeFact: Nuthatches wedge seeds into bark crevices, then hammer them open like tiny wood carpenters.

critters.name: Downy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Downy Woodpeckers drum on trees to communicate and find insects under the bark.
critters.activeFact: Downy woodpeckers have shock-absorbing skull structure that helps protect their brain while pecking.

critters.name: Hairy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Hairy Woodpeckers use their long tongues to extract insects from deep tree bark crevices.
critters.activeFact: Hairy woodpeckers use strong chisel beaks to pry insects from deeper bark than smaller woodpeckers.

critters.name: Pileated Woodpecker
critters.fact: Pileated Woodpeckers create large rectangular holes in trees to find insects and build nests.
critters.activeFact: Pileated woodpecker holes can become homes for other wildlife later, including owls and squirrels.

critters.name: Red-bellied Woodpecker
critters.fact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers drum rapidly to mark territory and communicate with other woodpeckers.
critters.activeFact: Red-bellied woodpeckers stash food in bark crevices to eat later, especially in colder months.

critters.name: Mourning Dove
critters.fact: Mourning Doves can fly up to 55 miles per hour, making them swift and agile fliers.
critters.activeFact: Mourning doves make a whistling sound with their wings when they take off fast.

critters.name: American Goldfinch
critters.fact: American Goldfinches molt twice a year, changing from bright yellow to dull olive-brown in winter.
critters.activeFact: Goldfinches have a bouncy, rollercoaster flight pattern thatâ€™s easy to recognize once you notice it.

critters.name: Dark-eyed Junco
critters.fact: Dark-eyed Juncos often form large flocks in winter, creating impressive swirling patterns in flight.
critters.activeFact: Juncos often scratch backward with both feet at once, like tiny feathered bulldozers under the feeder.

critters.name: House Finch
critters.fact: House Finches sing more varied songs than many other North American songbirds, impressing mates and rivals alike.
critters.activeFact: House finches can learn local song variations, so neighborhoods can have slightly different â€œdialects.â€

critters.name: Purple Finch
critters.fact: Purple Finches have a sweet, raspberry-like flavor often enjoyed by birds and humans alike.
critters.activeFact: Purple finches prefer woodland edges and often show up in bursts when cone crops and seeds are good.

critters.name: Wild Turkey
critters.summary: Large ground bird common in Michigan.
critters.fact: Wild turkeys can run up to 20 miles per hour and fly short distances at 55 miles per hour.
critters.activeFact: Wild turkeys roost in trees at night, even though they spend most of the day walking and foraging on the ground.

critters.name: Ruffed Grouse
critters.summary: Forest bird known for drumming display.
critters.fact: Ruffed Grouse create a unique drumming sound by rapidly beating their wings to attract mates.
critters.activeFact: Ruffed grouse â€œdrumâ€ by beating their wings so fast it sounds like a distant engine starting up.

critters.name: Sandhill Crane
critters.summary: Tall wetland bird with loud call.
critters.fact: Sandhill Cranes perform impressive, graceful dances to communicate and strengthen pair bonds.
critters.activeFact: Sandhill cranes are loud and social, often calling while flying to keep groups coordinated.

critters.name: American Crow
critters.fact: American Crows use tools like sticks to extract insects from tree bark and crevices.
critters.activeFact: Crows can work together to â€œmobâ€ a predator, chasing it away by teamwork and noise.

critters.name: Common Raven
critters.fact: Common Ravens can mimic sounds from their environment, including human speech and animal calls.
critters.activeFact: Ravens can do aerial flips and rolls, and sometimes play in wind currents just because they can.

critters.name: Red-tailed Hawk
critters.fact: Red-tailed Hawks can soar up to 1,200 feet while scanning for prey from above.
critters.activeFact: Red-tailed hawks often perch quietly for long periods, then strike fast when prey slips up.

critters.name: Cooperâ€™s Hawk
critters.fact: Cooperâ€™s Hawks are skilled fliers, weaving through trees to catch smaller birds mid-air during hunts.
critters.activeFact: Cooperâ€™s hawks are built for speed through trees, using long tails to steer like a fighter jet rudder.

critters.name: Mallard Duck
critters.fact: Mallard ducks can sleep with one eye open to stay alert for predators while resting.
critters.activeFact: Mallards often tip-up to feed, dunking their head underwater while their tail points straight up.

critters.name: Wood Duck
critters.summary: Colorful duck nesting in tree cavities.
critters.fact: Wood Ducks nest in tree cavities and are known for their vibrant, colorful plumage.
critters.activeFact: Wood duck ducklings can leap from nest cavities soon after hatching and land safely thanks to their light bodies.

critters.name: Canada Goose
critters.fact: Canada Geese can fly thousands of miles during migration using a distinctive V-shaped formation.
critters.activeFact: Canada geese take turns leading a flying V formation to reduce fatigue in long flights.

critters.name: Great Blue Heron
critters.fact: Great Blue Herons can hunt by standing still for minutes, then striking quickly to catch fish or amphibians.
critters.activeFact: Great blue herons fold their neck into an S-shape in flight, pulling the head back toward the shoulders.

critters.name: Painted Turtle
critters.fact: Painted turtles can absorb oxygen through their skin, allowing them to stay underwater for extended periods.
critters.activeFact: Painted turtles bask to warm up, then slip back into water fast when they sense footsteps or movement.

critters.name: Snapping Turtle
critters.fact: Snapping turtles can snap their jaws shut with incredible speed to catch prey quickly and efficiently.
critters.activeFact: Snapping turtles often stay motionless on the bottom, waiting to ambush fish or anything edible that drifts close.

critters.name: Bluegill
critters.fact: Bluegills can rapidly change color to communicate and camouflage within their environment.
critters.activeFact: Bluegill often hang near cover like weeds and logs, darting out to grab food and then vanishing again.

critters.name: Largemouth Bass
critters.fact: Largemouth Bass can expand their mouths wide to swallow prey nearly half their own body size.
critters.activeFact: Largemouth bass are ambush hunters that prefer to strike from cover instead of chasing long distances.

critters.name: Yellow Perch
critters.fact: Yellow Perch have distinct dark vertical stripes and can change color based on their environment.
critters.activeFact: Yellow perch often move in schools, which can confuse predators and improve feeding success.

critters.name: Northern Pike
critters.fact: Northern Pike can grow over 4 feet long and have sharp teeth for catching prey quickly.
critters.activeFact: Northern pike have a torpedo-shaped body built for sudden bursts, striking prey in a quick explosion of speed.

critters.name: Spring Peeper
critters.summary: Tiny frog with loud spring calls.
critters.fact: Spring Peepers can be heard chirping loudly during early spring evenings near wetlands and forests.
critters.activeFact: Spring peepers can sound much louder than their tiny size suggests, and choruses can carry across wetlands.

critters.name: American Bullfrog
critters.fact: American Bullfrogs can produce loud, deep calls that can be heard up to one mile away.
critters.activeFact: Bullfrogs often sit still at the waterline, then lunge fast to grab insects, small fish, or anything that fits.

critters.name: Green Frog
critters.fact: Green Frogs can be identified by the distinctive ridge running from their eyes down their back.
critters.activeFact: Green frogs often stay near the shoreline and dive into water at the first sign of footsteps or shadows.

critters.name: Leopard Frog
critters.fact: Leopard frogs can jump over 20 times their body length in a single leap.
critters.activeFact: Leopard frogs can make long, powerful jumps to escape, using legs built like springs.

critters.name: Garter Snake
critters.fact: Garter snakes can release a mild musk to deter predators when threatened.
critters.activeFact: Garter snakes are active hunters that use quick strikes and swallow prey whole, often near water and wet areas.

critters.name: Water Snake
critters.fact: Water snakes can stay underwater for up to two hours while hunting for fish and amphibians.
critters.activeFact: Water snakes are strong swimmers and can hold still underwater to avoid detection, then move when the coast is clear.

critters.name: Eastern Milk Snake
critters.fact: Eastern Milk Snakes mimic rattlesnake patterns to deter predators despite being nonvenomous and harmless.
critters.activeFact: Milk snakes are helpful rodent hunters and often live near barns, sheds, and woodpiles where mice are common.

critters.name: Monarch Butterfly
critters.fact: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles to overwinter in specific mountain forests in Mexico.
critters.activeFact: Monarchs navigate long distances using the sun as a guide, with an internal clock helping them keep direction.

critters.name: Swallowtail Butterfly
critters.fact: Swallowtail butterflies have distinctive tail-like extensions on their hindwings that mimic bird tails.
critters.activeFact: Swallowtails can â€œtasteâ€ with sensors on their feet to find the right plants for eggs and feeding.

critters.name: Dragonfly
critters.fact: Dragonflies can fly up to 30 miles per hour and control each wing independently for agile maneuvers.
critters.activeFact: Dragonflies are aerial hunters that can snatch insects mid-flight with their legs forming a basket.

critters.name: Damselfly
critters.fact: Damselflies can fold their wings along their bodies, unlike dragonflies that keep wings spread out.
critters.activeFact: Damselflies often rest with wings folded along their body, which helps distinguish them from dragonflies.

critters.name: Firefly
critters.fact: Fireflies produce light through a chemical reaction called bioluminescence to attract mates and communicate.
critters.activeFact: Different firefly species blink in different patterns, like each one has its own â€œlight code.â€

critters.name: Honeybee
critters.fact: Honeybees communicate by performing a waggle dance to share the location of food sources.
critters.activeFact: Honeybees can recognize patterns and learn routes, helping them return to the hive after long foraging trips.

critters.name: Bumblebee
critters.fact: Bumblebees can regulate their body temperature, allowing them to fly in cooler weather than most other bees.
critters.activeFact: Bumblebees can â€œbuzz pollinateâ€ by vibrating flowers to shake loose pollen like a tiny power tool.

critters.name: Grasshopper
critters.fact: Grasshoppers hear through organs located on their abdomen called tympanal organs.
critters.activeFact: Grasshoppers make sound by rubbing their legs or wings, and different species have different rhythms.
